questions.text: The discovery of 'gene transformation' came from the study (as shown in the image) of which one of the following bacteria:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows the famous Griffith experiment (1928) on mice using pneumococci (Streptococcus pneumoniae) strains, providing the direct evidence of the existence of transformation.
  • Transformation is the process of random uptake of a free or naked DNA fragment from the environment by a bacterial cell and incorporation into its chromosome in a heritable form.
  • He stated that the live noncapsulated strains were transformed into the capsulated strains due to the transfer of the capsular genes released from the lysis of the killed capsulated strains, which was confirmed later by Avery, Macleod, and McCarty in 1944.

questions.text: Virus-mediated transfer of bacterial DNA from one cell to another is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Virus-mediated transfer of bacterial DNA from one cell to another is known as Transduction.

  • Transduction is defined as the transmission of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage (a virus that infects bacteria).
  • Some bacterial toxins are acquired through this procedure
  • Example:
    • A - a & b toxin of Streptococcus pyogenes
    • B - c & d toxin of botulinum
    • C - cholera toxin
    • D - diphtheria toxin
    • E - enterohemorrhagic coli

Incorrect options:

Transformation (Option B) is the process of random uptake of a free or naked DNA fragment from the environment by a bacterial cell and incorporation into its chromosome in a heritable form.

Transcription (Option C) is the process of the formation of mRNA from DNA.

Conjugation (Option D) is a process of direct transfer of genetic elements through pili.

choices.text: Taking up soluble DNA fragments across their cell wall from other species
Incorporating part of the host DNA

questions.text: Bacteria may acquire characteristics by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bacteria are incapable of integrating Host DNA into their genetic material.
  • Bacteria may acquire characteristics by conjugation, transformation and transduction but not by incorporating host DNA directly.

Incorrect options:

Taking up soluble DNA fragments across their cell wall from other species (Option A) is called Transformation. This phenomenon is demonstrated in Griffith's experiment.

Transfer of genetic material through Bacteriophages (Option C) from one bacterium to another is called Transduction.

Conjugation (Option D): A process where genetic elements (F factor or chromosomal material) is transferred from donor bacterium to recipient bacterium by making physical contact through sex pilus.

Explanation:

Conjugation involves plasmids, F' ( F factor), and HFr. It doesn't involve bacteriophages. Bacteriophages are involved in Transduction.

Conjugation: A process where genetic elements (F factor or chromosomal material) are transferred from a donor bacterium to a recipient bacterium by making physical contact through a sex pilus.

  • Conjugation is of various types:
    • Simple conjugation
    • HFr (high frequency conjugation)
    • Sex-duction.
  • Resistance transfer in most of the bacteria is by conjugation
  • R factor (or the resistance factor) is a plasmid which has two components.
    • Resistance transfer factor (RTF) is the plasmid responsible for conjugational transfer (similar to F factor)
    • Resistance determinant (r): Codes for resistance to one drug
    • An R factor can have several r determinants so it is more dangerous and difficult to treat than mutational drug resistance which is due to single mutation.
  • Transferable Drug Resistance: Resistance transfer factor (RTF) + Resistant determinant(r) = Resistance (R)
  • Leads to multi-drug resistance, which is not easy to treat.

Simple conjugation;

  • Here F factor is transferred from donor (male) to recipient (female) through pili
  • (F+) + (F-) = F++ F+

HFr conjugation: F factor may get integrated into bacterial chromosome and can transfer chromosomal DNA along with plasmid. Such cells who are capable for transferring chromosomal DNA are called HFr cells and conjugation involving them is HFr conjugation.

  • HFr cell + F-cell = HFr + F- (recombinant)
  • IN HFr conjugation F- doesn't become F+ because here only some part F factor is transferred.

Sex-duction:

  • When F factor reverts from integrated to free state, it may carry some chromosomal material along with it such cells are F' (F prime) cells.
  • Conjugation involving F' cell is sex-duction
  • Here complete F factor along with some chromosomal material is transferred
  • F' Cell + F-Cell = F' Cell + F' Cell

questions.text: SYBR green dye is used for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

rt-PCR is real-time PCR in which we quantify the amplicon. For quantification, we use SYBR green dye.

  • SYBR Green I is a dsDNA binding dye, which can be used to quantify amplicon amount during the course of the PCR by tracking overall fluorescence emission.
  • The dye binds into the minor groove of dsDNA, and does not bind to ssDNA.
  • When bound, it increases its fluorescence by up to 100fold.

Incorrect options:

  • HPLC ( Option A) is chromatographic method used for diagnosis of sickle cell anemia, thalassemia.
  • ELISA (Option C) enzyme linked immunosorbent assay is a hybridisation technique based on antigen antibody binding, used for rapid diagnosis of diseases.
  • RT-PCR (Option D) is reverse transcriptase PCR where RNA is transcripted to DNA through reverse transcriptase and amplified.

choices.text: Real-time PCR can be used for multiple targets
Real-time PCR has no problem with inhibition
Real-time PCR is quicker and less susceptible to contamination
Real-time PCR is more amenable to quantification

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of real-time PCR over conventional PCR?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Advantages of Real-Time PCR over Conventional PCR (Block-based PCR):
    • Quicker (Option C ruled out)
    • Closed tube system, so less potential for contamination
    • More sensitive
    • Can be multiplexed to detect more than one target in a reaction (Option A ruled out)
    • Amenable to quantification (Determine viral load) (Option D ruled out)
    • More suited to automation
  • Problems common to both Real Time PCR and Block-based PCR:
    • PCR inhibition: But it can be controlled better in real-time PCR, as an internal control can be placed in multiplex with the target PCR to detect the presence of inhibition

choices.text: Analysis of spectra of cell wall proteins

questions.text: What is the principle of MALDI-TOF MSRIEF?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry is a process by which it identifies organisms based on the unique protein composition of the cell walls.
  • It does not detect DNA (Option D ruled out).

Incorrect options:

Detection of antigen and antibody (Option B) is usually done in elisa.

Detection of nucleic acid (Option C) is done in hybridisation techniques.

questions.text: All of the following are required in the Polymerase Chain Reaction except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dideoxy-ribonucleotides (ddNTPs) are used in Sanger sequencing.

Requirements of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR):

  • Taq polymerase: It is a thermostable DNA polymerase I named after the thermophilic eubacterial microorganism Thermus aquaticus (Option B ruled out)
  • Primers: They are short oligonucleotides complementary to a small sequence of the target DNA
  • Deoxynucleotide (Option A ruled out): Deoxynucleotide triphosphates (dNTPs) are the nucleoside triphosphates containing deoxyribose. They are the building blocks of DNA, and they lose two of the phosphate groups when incorporated into DNA during replication.
  • Mg++ ion (catalyst for kinases) (Option D ruled out)
  • Target DNA present in the sample

Procedure:

  1. Denaturation at 95 °C - this causes dsDNA to ssDNA
  2. Primer annealing at 55 °C - primer anneals to the complementary site on ssDNA
  3. Extension at 72 °C - extension of DNA by Taq polymerase, and the next cycle starts

dNTPs vs ddNTPs:

  • The Deoxyribonucleotide/deoxynucleotide (dNTPs) structurally have one hydroxyl group at the 3 position of the sugar of nucleotide.
  • The dNTPs are used in DNA sequencing and the Polymerase chain reaction, whilst the ddNTPs are only used in the Sanger sequencing technique to sequence DNA.
  • The dideoxynucleotides or the ddNTPs are the artificially synthesized special type of nucleotides used in the Sanger sequencing technique.
  • The dideoxynucleotides are known as the chain terminator nucleotides that abort the nucleotide chain due to lack of 3 OH group.
  • During the synthesis of DNA, the Taq DNA polymerase incorporates nucleotides to the growing DNA strand. First, it recognizes the 3 end of the primer and then starts the synthesis reaction. The reason is that it can't get the free 3 end to elongate the chain, the ddNTPs have two hydrogen groups but not hydroxyl! Hence the polynucleotide chain progression stops.
  • The end of the ddNTP-dideoxynucleotides are labeled with the color dye, the color signal is recorded by the computer.
  • The entire technique of sanger sequencing relies on the use of ddNTPs. ddATP, ddGTP, ddCTP and ddGTP when incorporated into the amplification reaction, the chain got terminated.

questions.text: Which technique is used in molecular biology research to study gene expression by the detection of RNA in a sample?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Northern blot is used to identify RNA.

Types of Blot techniques:

  • Northern blot - RNA
  • Western blot - Protein (Option D ruled out)
  • Southern blot - DNA (Option C ruled out)
  • Eastern blot - extension of western blot (Option A ruled out)

The northern blot, or RNA blot, is a technique used in molecular biology research to study gene expression by detection of RNA (or isolated mRNA) in a sample.

  • The principles of these techniques differ, but the basic procedure remains the same
  • Southern blot: based on DNA-DNA hybridisation
  • Northern blot: based on RNA-DNA hybridisation
  • Western blot: based on antigen-antibody binding
  • A Southern blot is a method used in molecular biology for detection of a specific DNA sequence in DNA samples. Southern blotting combines transfer of electrophoresis-separated DNA fragments to a filter membrane and subsequent fragment detection by probe hybridisation
  • Western blotting, is a molecular biological method based on the technique to detect protein-protein interaction in vitro. An antibody probe is used to detect a protein of interest.
  • The North-western blot, also known as the north-western assay, is a hybrid analytical technique of the western blot and the northern blot, and is used in molecular biology to detect interactions between RNA and proteins.
  • The eastern blot, or eastern blotting, is a biochemical technique used to analyze protein post-translational modifications including the addition of lipids, phosphates, and glycoconjugates. It is most often used to detect carbohydrate epitopes. Thus, eastern blot can be considered an extension of the biochemical technique of western blot

questions.text: Chromosomal mutation can be identified by all of the following techniques except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chromosomal mutations cannot be detected by Agarose gel electrophoresis.

  • Agarose Gel electrophoresis is used to separate the DNA by charge or by size.
    • It is usually performed to visualize the amplified DNA after PCR, but may be used as a preparative technique prior to use of other methods such as mass spectrometry, RFLP, PCR, cloning, DNA sequencing, or Southern blotting for further characterization.
    • It is only a method of visualizing the DNA after separating it by size. So, it is always used as a part of any molecular method to visualize the DNA. But alone it cannot be used to detect any mutations.

Incorrect options:

Single-strand conformation polymorphism (SSCP) (Option A) is defined as a conformational difference of single-stranded nucleotide sequences of identical length as induced by differences in the sequences under certain experimental conditions. This property allows sequences to be distinguished by means of gel electrophoresis, which separates fragments according to their different conformations. SSCP used to be a way to discover new DNA polymorphisms (variations/mutations) but is now being supplanted by sequencing techniques on account of efficiency and accuracy.

Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) (Option C) is a method by which fragments of partial 16S rDNA-amplified fragments of identical length but different sequence can be resolved electrophoretically because of their different melting behaviour in a gel system containing a gradient of denaturants. It can detect mutations.

Dideoxy-nucleotide trail DNA (Sanger) sequencing/Chain-termination DNA sequencing (Option D), also called the dideoxy-nucleotide procedure, is based on the principle that during DNA synthesis, addition of a nucleotide triphosphate requires a free hydroxyl group on the 3' carbon of the sugar of the last nucleotide of the growing DNA strand. as we can know the sequence of DNA, we can detect mutation in it.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with HIV presents for follow-up. His treatment includes a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). Which of the following enzymatic activities is targeted by this drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • RNA dependent DNA polymerase / Reverse transcriptase is an enzyme used by HIV to convert its viral RNA genome into DNA by a process called Reverse transcription.
  • It synthesizes DNA using RNA as a template,therefore classified as an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase.
  • Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) work by mimicking natural nucleosides, causing chain termination during DNA synthesis, thereby inhibiting viral replication.

Incorrect options:

DNA dependent RNA polymerase (Option A) is used in DNA transcription.

Transcription procedure:

  1. Initiation
    • DNA Unwinding:The DNA double helix unwinds to expose the template strand
    • RNA Polymerase Binding:The enzyme RNA polymerase binds to the promoter region of the DNA. This region is typically found just upstream of the coding sequence.
  2. Elongation
    • RNA Synthesis:RNA polymerase moves along the template strand of DNA in the 3' to 5' direction, synthesizing a single strand of mRNA in the 5' to 3' direction.
  3. Termination
    • Termination Signal:RNA polymerase continues elongating until it reaches a termination sequence in the DNA.
    • mRNA Release:Upon reaching the termination site, RNA polymerase detaches from the DNA, releasing the newly synthesized mRNA strand.
  4. Post-Transcriptional Modifications (in Eukaryotes)
    • 5' Capping:A modified guanine nucleotide is added to the 5' end of the mRNA for stability and recognition.
    • Polyadenylation:A string of adenine nucleotides (poly-A tail) is added to the 3' end, enhancing stability and facilitating export from the nucleus.
    • Splicing:Introns (non-coding regions) are removed, and exons (coding regions) are joined together to produce a mature mRNA molecule.

DNA dependent DNA polymerase (Option C) is an enzyme responsible for synthesizing DNA from a DNA

It is used in Replication process

DNA  dependent DNA polymerase is present in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes

  1. DNA Polymerase I:
    • Found in prokaryotes (like E. coli).
    • Primarily involved in DNA repair and the removal of RNA primers during DNA replication.
  2. DNA Polymerase II:
    • Also found in prokaryotes.
    • Plays a role in DNA repair
  3. DNA Polymerase III:
    • The main enzymefor DNA replication in prokaryotes.
    • Has high Conversion rate and a 3' to 5' exonuclease activity for proof-reading.
  4. Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases:
    • DNA Polymerase α:Initiates DNA synthesis and has primase activity.
    • DNA polymerase beta:involved in DNA repair
    • DNA Polymerase gamma:mitochondrial dna replication
    • DNA Polymerase δ:Involved in lagging-strand synthesis and DNA repair.
    • DNA Polymerase ε:Primarily responsible for leading-strand synthesis.

RNA dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) (Option D) is an enzyme that synthesizes RNA from an RNA template. RdRPs are found in various organisms, particularly in RNA viruses for replication

questions.text: In a 35-year-old patient, tuberculosis is suspected, but sputum smear microscopy is negative. To confirm the diagnosis, the physician orders a PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA. In the PCR process used for detecting M. tuberculosis DNA, what is the correct order of steps in each cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The order of the sequence in PCR is: Denaturation - annealing - extension.

  1. Denaturation at 95 centigrade - this causes dsDNA to ssDNA
  2. Primer annealing at 55 centigrade - primer anneals to complimentary site on ssDNA.
  3. Extension at 72 centigrade - extension of DNA by Taq polymerase and next cycle starts

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a powerful molecular biology technique used to amplify a specific segment of DNA

Clinical Applications:

  • Infectious Disease Diagnosis (e.g., COVID-19, HIV, TB, HPV)
  • Genetic Testing (e.g., cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia)
  • Forensics (DNA fingerprinting)
  • Cancer Research (detecting mutations)
  • Prenatal Testing (fetal genetic screening)

Types of PCR:
